info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades: The 1980s game 1.

(1, 1).clue: The U.K. was formed with the 1801 addition of Ireland to the realm of this king

(2, 1).clue: "And he gathered them together into a place called... Armageddon "

(3, 1).clue: This flavor jelly traditionally accompanies lamb

(4, 1).clue: Helena, Montana, 1901:This actor of Mr. Deeds & few words

(5, 1).clue: This "beastly" embrace is a Wall Street term for a takeover bid with a share price so high, the board can't refuse

(6, 1).clue: Cylindrical, like a breaking wave or certain bells

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a map on the monitor.)  By law, Roman generals couldn't lead forces out of their assigned province; Caesar's 49 B.C. crossing of this stream separating Cisalpine Gaul from Italy acted as a war declaration

(2, 2).clue: "Hatred stirreth up strifes: but love covereth all sins"

(3, 2).clue: Disneyland's Blue Bayou restaurant serves this fried sandwich that has ham, Swiss & turkey

(4, 2).clue: Near Lake George, New York, c. 1823:This photographer

(5, 2).clue: In the U.S. Army's definition, unsolicited back or neck rubs are examples of this 2-word offense

(6, 2).clue: 6-letter word for what you did when you fed the furnace

(1, 3).clue: In the 1930s Franco abolished the use of Euskara, the language of this ethnic group

(2, 3).clue: "But the Lord sent out a great wind into the sea, and there was a mighty tempest"

(3, 3).clue: This 6-letter word is used throughout India for a blend of spices, like the garam one

(4, 3).clue: St. Joseph, Michigan, 1992:This 2-time Sports Illustrated swimsuit edition cover model

(5, 3).clue: LBJ got physical when persuading or motivating; this "Happy Warrior" once showed reporters his leg scars

(6, 3).clue: Adjective for old, twisted hands or knotty wood

(1, 4).clue: In 1868 an enlightened emperor took over as leader of Japan from the man in this position

(2, 4).clue: "Vashti the queen made a feast for the women in the royal house which belonged to King Ahasuerus"

(3, 4).clue: This 2-word term means chemistry & physics have come to the kitchen; liquid nitrogen & lasers might be involved

(4, 4).clue: Austin, Texas, 1954:This former CEO of Hewlett-Packard

(5, 4).clue: In 2013 the frequency of this crime by gypsy children shut down the Louvre

(6, 4).clue: Adjective applied to differently abled 14th century conqueror Timur

(1, 5).clue: In 1914 the once & future St. Petersburg got this new name; 10 years later it became Leningrad

(2, 5).clue: (The first book) "O death, where is thy sting?  O grave, where is thy victory?"

(3, 5).clue: If you see this Italian word on a menu, know that it means eggplant

(4, 5).clue: New York City, 1885:This "Smoke Gets In Your Eyes" composer

(5, 5).clue: This word, the big no-no in intellectual property law, can also mean encroaching on personal space

(6, 5).clue: A unit used to measure X-ray exposure, equal to 100 ergs per gram

(1, 1).clue: The Mahabharata is an epic poem originally written in this ancient language

(2, 1).clue: That guy you work with who's always lounging around

(3, 1).clue: Almost the entire dry weight of a red blood cell consists of this protein

(4, 1).clue: Tunes in this '50s Broadway classic include "Gee, Officer Krupke" & "Cool"

(5, 1).clue: Things to see in this capital include the Vasa Ship Museum & the royal palace, home to King Carl XVI Gustav

(6, 1).clue: Your Latin lex-icon should include the fact that "lex" means this, as in "lex succurit ignoranti"

(1, 2).clue: Kafka wrote "The Metamorphosis"; this ancient Roman wrote "Metamorphoses"

(2, 2).clue: In Britain, people live in "council" ones

(3, 2).clue: When you swallow, this flap of cartilage acts like a lid to the larynx

(4, 2).clue: Mary Bridget Davies belts out "Me & Bobby McGee" in the 2013 show "A Night with" her

(5, 2).clue: This fourth-largest Spanish city was originally known as Hispalis

(6, 2).clue: From the Latin for "purse" come "purser" & this word for a college's treasurer

(1, 3).clue: Tolstoy's "Death of" this title character initially deals with others' reactions to his passing

(2, 3).clue: To increase stimulative government spending is to "prime" this

(3, 3).clue: The "T" in T cells refers to this gland where they mature

(4, 3).clue: This show with a street in its title had songs like "I'm Not Wearing Underwear Today"

(5, 3).clue: Although this Bosnian capital is largely Muslim, it does have a Jewish museum housed in the old synagogue

(1, 4).clue: In 1956 he published "La Chute", or "The Fall"; the next year he won the Nobel Prize for Literature

(2, 4).clue: Shape that laughing cow cheese comes in

(2, 5).clue: Ohio city once home to Big Ben (Roethlisberger)

(3, 5).clue: Take a gamble & name this longest cranial nerve, which runs from the brain through the neck & thorax to the abdomen

(4, 5).clue: "(Ya Got) Trouble" when ya go to see this hill of a show

(0, 0).clue: The only foreign-born First Lady was the wife of this man who served in the diplomatic corps from age 14
